questions.question: Identify the gene commonly involved in the carcinoma shown in the image below:
questions.explanation: papillary thyroid cancer. It is associated with BRAF V600 mutation. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are not associated with papillary thyroid cancer. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient presents with headaches, palpitations, and hypertension. On laboratory examination, urine VMA is positive. His biopsy findings are given below. Which of the following is a correct statement?
questions.explanation: pattern, which is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. It is associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A). Incorrect Options: Option A - Mostly malignant: Pheochromocytomas are mostly benign, only 10% malignant. Option B - Mostly in children: Pheochromocytomas are more common in adults; only 10% occur in children. Option C - Mostly bilateral: Pheochromocytomas are mostly unilateral, and only 10% are bilateral. Reference: .

questions.question: Which hormone is secreted by the structure marked with an arrow?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Glucocorticoid Explanation: The marked portion is Zona Fasciculata , which releases glucocorticoids. Layers of Adrenal Gland Adrenal Cortex Zones of the cortex Hormones produced Main function Morphology of Zone Zona Glomerulosa Mineralocorticoid (Option D ruled out) Aldosterone(main) Deoxycorticosterone Maintenance of sodium balance Small clumps of cells Zona fasciculata Glucocorticoids (Option A) Cortisol Corticosterone Maintenance of sugars Columnar cells that form long cords Zona reticularis Sex steroids Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) (Option B ruled out) Androstenedione (Option C ruled out) Maintenance of sexual functioning Network of intercalated cells Adrenal medulla Medulla Catecholamines: Norepinephrine Epinephrine Small amounts of dopamine Carbohydrate and fat metabolisms Fight or flight responses Specialised sympathetic ganglion Clumps and strands of chromaffin cells Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 329-333. Textbook of Physiology, G. K Pal, 1st Edition, Page 507.

questions.question: Which of the following is a new intranuclear immunohistochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumors?
questions.explanation: neuroendocrine tumors that is intranuclear. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are not intranuclear immunohistochemistry markers for neuroendocrine tumors. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient presents with neck swelling with compression of the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nest and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the origin of the tumor?
questions.explanation: suggests the likelihood of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. It originates from the Parafollicular C cells. Incorrect Options: Options B & D - Hurthle cells & Askanazy cells: Hurthle cells or Askanazy cells are seen in Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. They are not associated with medullary carcinoma. Option C - Follicular cells: Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid carcinomas but not medullary carcinoma. Reference: .

questions.question: A 26-year-old female patient presents with a palpable thyroid nodule and occasional neck discomfort. She has no history of radiation exposure to the neck. On physical examination, a solitary, firm, non-tender thyroid nodule is noted. Ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic nodule with microcalcifications. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is performed, and histological analysis reveals characteristic nuclear changes. What is the most common thyroid cancer in this patient?
questions.explanation: in young adults. It often presents as a solitary thyroid nodule, and its characteristics on ultrasound, such as hypoechoic appearance and microcalcifications, along with the patient's demographic and clinical profile, are consistent with the case described. Papillary carcinoma is known for its characteristic nuclear changes, including nuclear grooves and pseudoinclusions. It usually has an excellent prognosis with a high survival rate. Incorrect Options: Option B - Follicular carcinoma: This type of thyroid cancer also presents as a thyroid nodule. However, it is less common than papillary carcinoma. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy alone might not be able to distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. Histopathological examination of the tumor capsule and vascular invasion is required to make the distinction. Option C - Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is associated with calcitonin production. It is typically not associated with microcalcifications on ultrasound and does not have the characteristic nuclear changes mentioned in the case. It's less common than papillary carcinoma and is often familial or associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes. Option D - Anaplastic carcinoma: This is an aggressive and rare type of thyroid cancer. It usually presents with rapid growth, hoarseness, dyspnea (difficulty breathing), and is commonly seen in older patients. It is not associated with the characteristic nuclear changes mentioned in the case and does not typically present with microcalcifications. Reference: .

questions.question: A 19-year-old female presents with a neck swelling that shifts during swallowing. Ultrasound reveals a 2 cm x 2 cm mass in the left lobe of the thyroid, reaching the strap muscles. Histopathology shows findings as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: findings of a mass in the thyroid reaching the strap muscles, raises suspicion for a thyroid pathology. The histopathology showing papillae lined with overlapping nuclei and the characteristic " Orphan Annie eye" nuclei is highly indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid . Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: This is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterized by lymphatic spread. It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy. Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion HPE shows: True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core. Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI). Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus. Presence of psammoma bodies: Dystrophic calcifications It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies. Medullary Carcinoma of the Thyroid (Option A) arises from the parafollicular C cells , which produce calcitonin. The provided histopathology does not show the typical features of medullary carcinoma, such as nests or clusters of polygonal cells with amyloid deposits. Follicular Carcinoma of the Thyroid (Option B) arises from the thyroid follicular cells. The histopathology image does not display the characteristic features of follicular carcinomas, such as invasion of the tumour capsule or blood vessels. Thyroglossal Cyst (Option C) is a congenital anomaly resulting from the persistence of thyroglossal duct remnants. It typically presents as a midline neck swelling that moves

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with a swelling in the midline of the neck, based on the biopsy findings, which reveal orphan Annie's eye nuclei as depicted in the image provided?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Papillary carcinoma Explanation: Papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common thyroid cancer, is characterised by "orphan Annie's eye" nuclei, which appear empty with a pale, ground-glass appearance under microscopy. Papillary carcinoma thyroid: It is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterised by lymphatic spread. It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy. Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion. HPE shows True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core. Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI). Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus. Presence of psammoma bodies: Dystrophic calcifications It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies. Follicular carcinoma (Option A) is a malignant thyroid tumour of follicular cells lacking papillary carcinoma’s distinctive features. It typically affects older individuals and presents as a solitary thyroid mass or, less commonly, as bone metastases. It is more cellular, with a thick, irregular capsule, necrosis, and frequent mitotic activity. Toxic nodular goitre (Option C) , also known as Plummer disease or a toxic multi-nodular goitre (MNG), is characterised by a hormonally active and leads to hyperthyroidism. Treatment often includes radioactive iodine, which is absorbed by the thyroid and destroys hormone-producing cells, reducing or eliminating hormone production and potentially decreasing the size of the goitre. Medullary carcinoma (Option D) of the thyroid (MTC), a neuroendocrine tumour, originates from the C cells of the thyroid, which produce calcitonin. MTC accounts for less than 5% of all thyroid cancers. Unlike other thyroid cancers, MTC does not accumulate radioiodine but secretes calcitonin. Symptoms may include a

questions.question: A patient presented to the OPD with long hands and feet and a protruding lower jaw. Which of the following genes is most likely implicated in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) PIT1 Explanation: The features of long hands and feet, along with a protruding lower jaw, are characteristic of acromegaly , often caused by overproduction of growth hormone (GH). The gene most commonly implicated in this condition is PIT1 (Pituitary-specific gene), a transcription factor that regulates the development and function of pituitary cells responsible for GH production, particularly: Somatotrophs (Growth hormone-producing cells) Lactotrophs (Prolactin-producing cells) Thyrotrophs (TSH-producing cells). PIT1 is essential for the differentiation of specific pituitary cell types during embryonic development. Its mutations or dysregulation can lead to abnormal pituitary function, causing excess growth hormone production and acromegaly. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1066, 1068.

questions.question: What is the minimum biopsy specimen requirement for an adequate sample in the case of a thyroid biopsy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 6 follicular cell clusters containing 10-15 cells Explanation: For an adequate thyroid biopsy, the specimen should ideally contain at least 6 follicular cell clusters, each having 10-15 cells. Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is a minimally invasive diagnostic procedure to evaluate abnormalities in various tissues, including thyroid nodules. Provides cytological details but not the Architecture. It is useful in papillary/medullary (amyloid)/anaplastic carcinomas, colloid nodules, and autoimmune or granulomatous thyroiditis. A 23G needle is used. Suspicious solitary/multiple nodules/ dominant nodules should be aspirated. A minimum of six aspirations should be done. An adequate FNAC smear should have six aspirations with six groups of cells, each containing 20 cells. USG-guided aspiration is better. Diagnostic accuracy of FNAC is 95%; sensitivity 85%; specificity 94%. Classification of FNAC reports: Thy 1 Non-diagnostic Thy 1c Non-diagnostic cystic Thy 2 Non-neoplastic Thy 3 Follicular Thy 4 Suspicion of malignancy Thy 5 Malignant Limitations of FNAC: Follicular Neoplasms: FNAC cannot differentiate between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma because it does not provide information about the capsule or vascular invasion . A further biopsy is needed for a definitive diagnosis. Riedel’s Thyroiditis: In this, the thyroid gland is replaced by fibrous tissue, which can result in a poor yield of cells, reducing the effectiveness of FNAC. Thyroid Lymphoma: FNAC may not provide sufficient information to diagnose thyroid lymphoma accurately. A biopsy is required to obtain tissue samples for specific markers and a more comprehensive diagnosis. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 866 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 449

questions.question: A patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. A biopsy reveals Orphan Annie's eye nuclei, as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Papillary carcinoma Explanation: The above features and HPE showing psammoma bodies, nuclear grooves, and "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei indicate papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common type of thyroid cancer & characterised by lymphatic spread. It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy. Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion. Histopathological Features: True papillae- Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core. Orphan Annie eye nuclei - Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI). Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus. Presence of psammoma bodies- dystrophic calcifications It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies.

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hashimoto thyroiditis Explanation: The clinical scenario with thyroid swelling and elevated TSH levels & presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies along with the presence of hurthle cells points towards Hashimoto thyroiditis. Hashimoto thyroiditis: An autoimmune disorder that causes chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism. The characteristic features include elevated TSH levels (due to thyroid failure) and the presence of thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies , which attack the thyroid tissue. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is characterised by painless enlargement of the thyroid, commonly in middle-aged women. The enlargement of the gland is generally symmetric and diffuse. In histopathology, there is extensive lymphocytic infiltration with well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hürthle cells, that represent a metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury. The thyroid parenchyma contains a dense lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal centres. Graves' disease (Option B) is an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism, characterised by low TSH levels and the presence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), not thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Hurthle cells are not a feature of Graves’ disease. Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid (Option C) is a malignant tumour of the thyroid, usually presenting with a solitary nodule and not typically associated with Hurthle cells or elevated TSH levels. Histopathologically, it features follicular cells arranged in a follicular pattern , with capsular and vascular invasion . Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (Option D) is a neuroendocrine cancer arising from the C-cells of the thyroid, and it is associated with elevated calcitonin levels. Histopathologically, it features polygonal or spindle-shaped cells arranged in nests or follicles , with amyloid deposits often present.

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who has swelling in the middle of their neck, along with weight loss, and a thyroid biopsy showing the presence of 'Orphan Annie eye nuclei?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Papillary thyroid carcinoma Explanation: The histopathological features of psammoma bodies, nuclear grooves, and "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei are indicative of papillary thyroid carcinoma. It is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterised by lymphatic spread. It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy. Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion HPE shows True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core. Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI). Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus. Presence of psammoma bodies: Dystrophic calcifications. It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies. Follicular thyroid carcinoma (Option A) typically does not exhibit "Orphan Annie eye nuclei." Instead, it is characterised by follicular cell differentiation and the presence of follicular patterns. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma (Option C) is a highly aggressive and undifferentiated form of thyroid cancer. It typically does not exhibit "Orphan Annie eye nuclei." Instead, it is characterised by marked cellular pleomorphism and loss of cellular differentiation. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (Option D) arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland and is associated with the production of calcitonin.

questions.question: A patient presents with a painless neck swelling . The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: infiltration and follicular cell changes with a history of painless progression, the most likely diagnosis is Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The hallmark of Hashimoto's thyroiditis includes Hurthle cells, characterized by abundant mitochondria giving a pink color, although they are not specific and can occur in other thyroid disorders. Incorrect Options: Option A - Medullary Carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma arises from the parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland, presenting with elevated calcitonin levels, diarrhea, amyloid stroma, and a familial link to pheochromocytoma or hyperparathyroidism, associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B. Option B - NHL: While NHL can affect the thyroid gland, its histology typically shows malignant lymphoid cells infiltrating the tissue, unlike the image provided. Option C - Graves Disease: Graves disease involves hyperthyroidism, goiter, and thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) stimulating excess thyroid hormone production. Microscopically, it shows pseudopapillae resembling true papillae seen in papillary carcinoma, with fibrovascular cores and colloid scalloping indicating colloid consumption.

questions.question: A 34-year-old male comes to the outdoor patient department with complaints of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating . On physical examination, his chest shows pectus excavatum and a high extremities-to-body ratio . Growth is seen on her tongue, and a mass on the left flank is also palpated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: pectus excavatum, high extremities-to-body ratio, tongue growth, and a flank mass are characteristic of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B). MEN 2B is an autosomal dominant genetic syndrome caused by a mutation in the RET proto-oncogene. It is associated with the development of multiple endocrine tumors, such as medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenomas. MEN 2B is also characterized by distinctive physical features, including marfanoid habitus (high extremities-to-body ratio), mucosal neuromas (growth on the tongue), and gastrointestinal ganglioneuromas. Incorrect Options: Option A - MEN 1: MEN 1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1) is characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine glands, including the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary gland. It does not typically present with the specific physical features described in the patient. Option B - MEN 2A: MEN 2A is another form of multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by RET gene mutations. It is characterized by the development of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism. The physical features associated with MEN 2B, such as marfanoid habitus and mucosal neuromas, are not typically seen in MEN 2A. Option D - Neurofibromatosis type 2: Neurofibromatosis type 2 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) and other central nervous system tumors. It does not typically present with the specific physical features described in the patient. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Pheochromocytoma produces all, except:
questions.explanation: adrenal medulla, resulting in excessive production of catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine. These tumors can produce various hormones and vasoactive substances. They do not produce secretin. Secretin is a hormone produced by the S cells of the duodenum. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D: Pheochromocytomas produce. Reference: Prepladder Notes
